hints_raw: Find <math> a\ </math> with help of <math>\ h(1)=1</math>.
question: 8 (b)
sols_html:
By knowing that \(h(1)=1\), we calculate

\(1=h(1)=2a(e^{\frac12}-1)\)

\[\begin{aligned} a=\frac{1}{2(e^{\frac12}-1)}.\end{aligned}\]

So, the function of height is

\(h(t)=\frac{e^{\frac{t}{2}}-1}{e^{\frac12}-1}.\)
sols_latex:
By knowing that $h(1)=1$, we calculate

$1=h(1)=2a(e^{\frac12}-1)$

\begin{align*}
a=\frac{1}{2(e^{\frac12}-1)}.
\end{align*}

So, the function of height is

$h(t)=\frac{e^{\frac{t}{2}}-1}{e^{\frac12}-1}.$
sols_raw:
By knowing that <math> \ h(1)=1</math>, we calculate

<math> 1=h(1)=2a(e^{\frac12}-1)</math>

:<math> a=\frac{1}{2(e^{\frac12}-1)}</math>.

So, the function of height is

<math> h(t)=\frac{e^{\frac{t}{2}}-1}{e^{\frac12}-1}.</math>
statement_html:
The growth rate of a plant during the first week after germination is given by

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle g(t) = ae^{t/2} \text{ mm/day},\end{aligned}\]

where the time t is measured in days, and a is a constant.

On the first day, the plant grew 1mm. Determine the constant a.
statement_latex:
The growth rate of a plant during the first week after germination is
given by

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle g(t) = ae^{t/2} \text{ mm/day},
\end{align*}

where the time \emph{t} is measured in days, and \emph{a} is a constant.

On the first day, the plant grew 1mm. Determine the constant \emph{a}.
statement_raw:
The growth rate of a plant during the first week after germination is given by

:<math> \displaystyle g(t) = ae^{t/2} \text{ mm/day}, </math>

where the time ''t'' is measured in days, and ''a'' is a constant.

On the first day, the plant grew 1mm. Determine the constant ''a''.
